project.name: jspec
project.description: JSON-based specification format for rapid AI agent context retrieval. Provides jspec-template as a starter template for projects.

architecture.philosophy: Provide AI agents with structured, queryable context to eliminate codebase exploration overhead

conventions.internal_specs: Specs prefixed with __ are internal/meta specs (e.g., '__jspec')
conventions.versioning: Semantic versioning for the spec format itself

decisions.title: Use single JSON file as source of truth
decisions.context: AI agents waste time exploring codebases. Need fast, precise context retrieval.
decisions.decision: Use single .jspec/source.json file with structured data, queryable via jq
decisions.consequences: Agents get instant context. Must maintain spec alongside code. JSON parsing overhead minimal.

decisions.title: Use object for specs instead of array
decisions.context: Need to avoid duplicate keys and enable direct access
decisions.decision: Use object with unique keys for specs: {"spec-name": {...}}
decisions.consequences: Direct access via jq '.specs["name"]'. Natural key uniqueness. Slightly more verbose queries for filtering.

decisions.title: Use __ prefix for internal specs
decisions.context: Need to distinguish internal jspec infrastructure from user specs
decisions.decision: Prefix internal/meta specs with __ (double underscore) to clearly mark them as part of jspec itself
decisions.consequences: Users can easily identify and avoid modifying internal specs. Clear separation of concerns between framework and user content.

__jspec.description: Internal jspec system specification - contains all jspec infrastructure components
__jspec.note: This is an internal spec. User specs should not use the __ prefix.

any additional fields relevant to the spec

hierarchical_specifications.description: Specs can contain nested child specifications at any depth using arbitrary keys
hierarchical_specifications.auto_draft_rule: ANY modification to a spec (except direct status changes) automatically sets status to 'draft'. Modifying child specs also sets parent to 'draft'.
hierarchical_specifications.philosophy: Instead of redoing implementations, refine specs by adding more detailed child specifications to achieve more accurate results

cli.description: Bash CLI tool for managing .jspec/source.json files

commands.add-spec: Add a new spec with ID, type, description, and tags
commands.update-spec: Update a field in an existing spec
commands.get: Get a specific spec by ID

cli.purpose: Provide a human-friendly CLI interface for creating and managing jspec files without manual JSON editing

depth-system.description: Single unified agent architecture where jspec-worker handles all operations from high-level management to detailed implementation
depth-system.purpose: Simplified architecture with one agent that can handle any jspec task

spec_levels.simple: Single file, small component, or focused investigation
spec_levels.medium: Module, service, or feature with multiple files
spec_levels.complex: System, architecture, or large-scale feature spanning multiple modules

concepts.unified_approach: Single agent handles both management operations (add/update/validate specs) and implementation work (read/implement/verify specs)

agent_responsibilities.jspec-worker: Handles ALL operations: extends specs, validates structure, analyzes codebase, implements features, explains specs, and verifies implementations

worker.description: Unified agent for managing and implementing jspec specifications - handles both high-level management operations and detailed implementation work
worker.purpose: Single agent that can extend, validate, maintain jspec files AND read/implement individual specs

management: Analyze specs and provide recommendations (analyze command)
implementation: Read and explain spec details (explain command)
Implement specs according to requirements (implement command)

commands.extend: Add a new spec to the jspec file
commands.validate: Validate the jspec structure and check for inconsistencies
commands.analyze: Analyze the current jspec structure and provide recommendations
commands.suggest-specs: Suggest missing specs based on codebase analysis
commands.sync: Ensure jspec is in sync with actual codebase structure
commands.test-sync: Verify that all specs have corresponding implementations
commands.implement: Implement a spec according to its requirements
commands.explain: Read and explain a specific spec's details
commands.verify: Verify if a spec is implemented correctly

traceability.description: Guideline for creating traceable specs with implementation status tracking using task arrays
traceability.purpose: Define a standardized pattern for tracking implementation tasks within specs to ensure clear traceability between specification and actual code
traceability.concept: When creating code-related specs, include a tasks array where each element is a task object containing name, description, and done status

task_structure.name: string - Short name for the task
task_structure.description: string - Detailed description of what needs to be done
task_structure.done: boolean - false when not implemented, true when implemented

traceability.rationale: Provides granular tracking of implementation progress with self-documenting task objects, enables clear verification of spec completion, maintains natural ordering, and keeps traceability between requirements and code
traceability.when_to_use: Propose this pattern when user creates specs that involve code implementation (files, components, APIs, features, etc.)

tasks.name: Add validation
tasks.description: Add input validation for request parameters

tasks.name: Write tests
tasks.description: Write unit tests for the endpoint

best_practices: Order tasks in logical sequence (implementation order)
Use concise but clear names for tasks
Provide detailed descriptions explaining what each task involves
Set all task.done to false initially when spec is created
Update task.done to true as each component is implemented
Consider updating overall spec status to active when all tasks are done
advantages: Natural ordering - tasks appear in implementation sequence
Easy to iterate - can use array methods and jq array operations
Simple indexing - access by position (tasks[0], tasks[1], etc.)
Clean structure - no need for numbered keys
Easy to add/remove tasks without renumbering
traceability.agent_behavior: When user requests to create a spec related to code, suggest including the tasks array pattern and offer to add task objects based on the spec requirements
